Fig. 1 a) Various possible Si environmental in the SAPO-34 framework: (a) isolated Si; (b) independent Si-Al-Si pair; (c) nonisolated Si(4Al) species; (d) Si-Al phase, and (e) Si island (oxygen atoms are not represented for clarity). Reprinted from [23] with permission from ACS Publications; b) Framework of the CHA cage, made up of 4-, 6-, and 8-membered rings (MR). Reprinted from [24] with permission from ACS Publications. Fig 1: Fig. 2 a) Skeleton structure diagram of the unit cell of SAPO-34. Each solid circle represents an Al, P, or Si, and the open circles represent oxygen. Reprinted from [40] with permission from Elsevier; b) CHA cage in Cu-SAPO-34 with detailed structures of ZCuOH and Z2Cu. The atoms are colored according to their elements: pink = Al, baby blue = P, yellow = Si, red = O, dark green = Cu, and gray = H. Reprinted from [47] with permission from the Royal Society of Chemistry. Fig 2: Fig. 3 Generation of Cu-SAPO-34 via the liquid ion-exchange procedure and the results of NH3-SCR for Cu-SAPO-34 prepared via ammonia assistant method and liquid ion-exchange. x-Cu-SAPO prepared by controlling NH3 adsorption temperature (x = 100–300 stays for NH3 adsorption temperature), L-Cu-SAPO prepared by the liquid ion-exchange. Reprinted from [57] with permission from Elsevier. Fig 3: Fig. 4 (Left) Pseudocolor representation of the special difference in Kα X-ray intensity for Cu in (a) as-prepared Cu-SAPO-34 and (b) Cu-SAPO-34 after activation at 750 °C. (Right) comparison of normalized X-ray intensities for Si (purple), Al (green), and Cu (blue) in as-prepared Cu-SAPO-34 (top) and after activation (bottom). Data were extracted from the maps at the areas indicated by the yellow lines and averaged over 10 pixels, corresponding to the line thickness. Reprinted from [59] with permission from ACS publications. Fig 4: Fig. 5 a) NO conversion during NH3-SCR (0.05 vol.-% NO, 0.05 vol.-% NH3, 10 vol.-% O2 and 10 vol.-% H2O) over Cu-SAPO-34 and amounts of isolated Cu2+ and CuxO y clusters estimated by H2-TPR. Reprinted from [74] with permission from Elsevier; b) Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra of Cu-SAPO-34 formed by calcining the 15 mg CuO + SAPO-34 mixture to various temperatures and periods. The amounts of EPR active Cu2+ ions are also tabulated. Reprinted from [75] with permission from Elsevier. Fig 5: Fig. 6 a) SEM and TEM images of micro-/mesoporous Cu-SAPO-34. Reprinted from [79] with permission from Elsevier; b) Preparation steps of micro-/mesoporous SAPO-34. Reprinted from [82] with permission from Elsevier. Fig 6: Fig. 7 a) Formation of hydrogen bond over NH3 and adsorbed water molecule. Reprinted from [99] with permission from Elsevier; b) Results of NH3-SCR for Cu-SSZ-13, Cu-SAPO-34, Cu-SSZ-16, and Cu-ZSM-5 after 14 h hydrothermal treatment (in a gas stream composed of 5 vol.-% H2O, 10 vol.-% O2, N2 balance, 750 °C). Reprinted from [27] with permission from Elsevier. Fig 7: Fig. 8 a) Activity comparison of Cu/SAPO-34(MO, TEA, TEAOH, and ACS) for low-temperature NH3-SCR. Exp-2: 8 vol.-% O2, 5 vol.-% H2O at 600 °C for 0.5 h; Exp-4: 8 vol.-% O2, 5 vol.-% H2O at 70 °C for 5 h; Exp-7: 8 vol.-% O2 at 700 °C for 1 h. Reprinted from [134] with permission from the Royal Society of Chemistry; b) Deterioration of SAPO-34 and Cu2+ protection in Cu-SAPO-34 in the presence of H2O. Reprinted from [67] with the permission of Elsevier. Fig 8: Fig. 9 a) The proposed deterioration mechanism of Cu-SAPO-34 with varying the crystal sizes in the presence of H2O at 70 °C. pre-treatment: 10 vol.-% O2, N2 balance, 500 °C, 1 h 0.05 vol.-% NH3, 0.05 vol.-% NO, 10 vol.-% O2, 10 vol.-% H2O, N2 balance, 5000 ml min−1, GHSV 27,100 h− 1 250–500 °C not shown [119] Recent progress in the selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 on Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts Magdalena Jabłońska Institute of Chemical Technology, Universität Leipzig, Linnéstr. 3, 04103 Leipzig, Germany Institute of Chemical Technology Universität Leipzig Linnéstr. 3 Leipzig 04103 Germany Institute of Chemical Technology, Universität Leipzig, Linnéstr. 3, 04103 Leipzig, Germany In recent years, Cu-exchanged small pore zeolites, such as Cu-SSZ-13 and Cu-SAPO-34, have been commercially applied in diesel after-treatment systems. Several tremendous research articles have been reported on Cu-CHA investigated in NH3-SCR, which makes this mini-review timely to provide inspirations for future material development. In the main body of this work, the preparation procedures of Cu-SAPO-34, the operating temperature ranges with NO x reduction activity/by-product formation, the poisoning and deactivation mechanisms as well as NH3-SCR reaction mechanisms over copper-containing SAPO-34 are reviewed. Last but not least, a summary and outlook are given to highlight promising candidates together with expected research directions in developing Cu-SAPO-34 for NH3-SCR. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords NH3-SCR chabazite SAPO-34 Hydrothermal stability Reaction mechanisms 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NO x , referring to NO and NO2, in proportions of about 90% and 10%, respectively) are major air pollutants, which contribute to serious environmental issues (such as acid rain, photochemical smog, ozone depletion, greenhouse effects, and haze (fine particle) pollution events) as well as harm human health [1,2]. NO x emissions come mainly from the combustion of fossil fuels in industrial processes, i.e., coal and fuel oil combustion in coal-fired power plants (stationary sources) and motor vehicles (mobile sources). The European standard regulations (Euro VI; 2014–2020) established the limits for NO x emissions as 0.06 g km−1 (for gasoline engines) and 0.08 g km−1 (for diesel engines) [3]. Thus, the catalytic elimination of harmful NO x compounds is an important and challenging task. To meet the stringent emission standards, three-way catalyst (TWC) technology, NO x storage and reduction (NSR, LNT), and selective catalytic reduction of NO x with ammonia (NH3-SCR) have been intensively explored to reduce NO x emissions. While NH3-SCR is recognized as the most efficient technology for reducing NO x emissions (i.e., to comply with current NO x emissions limits generally about 150–500 °C) in the presence of excess oxygen according to the standard SCR reaction (Eq. (1)). The increasing quantities of NO2 - due to the oxidation of NO to NO2 in the presence of diesel oxidation catalyst (DOC) upstream of SCR catalyst, lead to a fast SCR reaction (Eq. (2)) where equimolar NO and NO2 react with NH3. However, in leaner conditions (c(O2)/c(NO2) = 0), a NO2-SCR reaction as shown in Eq. (3) is proceeded. (1) 4 N H 3 + 4 NO + O 2 → 4 N 2 + 6 H 2 O s t a n d a r d S C R (2) NO + N O 2 + 2 N H 3 → 2 N 2 + 3 H 2 O f a s t S C R (3) 6 N O 2 + 8 N H 3 → 7 N 2 + 12 H 2 O N O 2 − S C R Various SCR catalysts have been widely explored in the past decades, including the state-of-the-art V-based (WO3/Mo3-V2O5-TiO2) catalysts [4,5], oxides and supported oxides (e.g., MnO x [6], perovskites LaMnO3/CeO2 [7], hydrotalcite-derived mixed metal oxides CuMgAlO x , Ce/MgAlFeO x [8]), hybrid metal oxide-zeolite catalysts (e.g., MnO x -CeO2-Fe-BEA, MnO x -Fe-ZSM-5) [9], etc. The recently published reviews focus on particular one type of catalysts (such as Mn-containing oxide catalysts [10], CeO2-TiO2 based catalysts [11], etc.) or group of materials (such as modified layered zeolites and cationic layered clay minerals [12], hybrid metal oxide-zeolite catalysts [9], etc.) applied in NH3-SCR. Since the discovery of Cu-ZSM-5 as an efficient catalyst for NO x removal in 1986 by Iwamoto et al. [13], copper- and/or iron-exchanged zeolite catalysts (e.g., Cu-SSZ-13, Cu-TNU-9, Fe-ZSM-5) [14,15], have been broadly investigated as well. Fe-based zeolites are generally active at higher temperatures (above 400 °C) as compared to Cu-based zeolites which operate better at lower temperatures (below 400 °C) [16]. In view of that, efficient Fe3+/Fe2+ redox cycling required higher temperatures than that of Cu2+/Cu+. Especially copper-based small pore molecular sieves with typical chabazite (CHA) framework, such as Cu-SAPO-34 and Cu-SSZ-13 have received wide attention and have been commercialized as the NH3-SCR catalysts in diesel engines for their broad activity window and high selectivity to N2. In the present mini-review, the focus will be on the investigation/application of Cu-SAPO-34 in NH3-SCR reported in the literature. Aluminophosphates (AlPOs) and silicoaluminophosphates (SAPOs) molecular sieves were firstly reported by Union Carbide in the 1980s [17,18]. Silicoaluminophosphates (SAPOs) are a class of microporous materials with a structure that is similar to that of zeolites and AlPOs (i.e., microporous AlPO4). The silicon for phosphorous substitution in AlPOs creates the Brønsted acid sites (i.e., ion-exchange properties) in SAPO materials [19,20]. The incorporation of silicon atoms into the AlPO4–34 framework can proceed according to two different substitution mechanisms, i.e., the SM2 mechanism (in which one silicon replaces one phosphorous), and the SM3 mechanism (in which two silicon atoms replace the neighboring aluminum and phosphorous) [21,22]. According to the above substitution mechanisms, the Al content should be less than the total contents of Si and P together. Otherwise more terminal groups or defects may appear, leading to the formation of hierarchical pores. If one P atom is replaced by Si and H, the Si(4Al) structure forms. If Si atoms substitute the adjacent Al and P atoms, the Si(nAl) (n = 0–3) structure as islands appeared [22]. Fig. 1 a shows the various possible Si environments in the SAPO-34 framework (4) Si(4Al) (3) Si(3Al) (2) Si(2Al) (1) Si(1Al) (0) Si(0Al) [23]. SAPO-34 is isomorphic to the natural small pore zeolite chabazite (CHA). Its topology may be described as layers of double six-membered rings (6-MR) that are interconnected by units of 4-MR. The double 6-MR layers stack in an ABC sequence, leading to a framework with a regular array of large barrel-shaped cages (with 0.94 nm in diameter), interconnected by a small 8-MR window (0.38 × 0.38 nm) (Fig. 1b). The cost for the synthesis of SAPO-34 is much lower than that of SSZ-13 that is limited due to the high cost of the template N,N,N-trimethyl-1-adamantammonium hydroxide (TMAdaOH). SAPO-34 can be synthesized by low-cost structure-directing agents (SDAs) such as morpholine (MOR), diethylamine (DEA), trimethylamine (TEA), tetraethylammonium hydroxide (TEAOH), and propylamine (PA), etc. As a result, the elemental composition, local microscopic structure, and morphology, the dispersion of Si in SAPO-34 may change with the use of different SDA, the Al and Si source, the molar ratio of n(Si)/n(Al)/n(P)/n(template) of the gel, the reaction temperature and reaction time, etc. SAPO-34 is the most interesting material in the SAPO family from the point of view of the application in the heterogeneous catalysis e.g., in the methanol-to-olefin (MTO) process [25,26] or the selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 (NH3-SCR; as Cu-SAPO-34 presented in the next chapter). Furthermore, among small-pore zeolites/silicoaluminophospates, Cu-SAPO-34 revealed similar or even higher activity during NO x removal than Cu-SSZ-13 in a wide range of temperatures (e.g., [27–30]). E.g., Ma et al. [29] found higher catalytic activity (also higher oxidation rate from NO to NO2) together with lower N2O selectivity over (1.0 wt.-%)Cu-SAPO-34 than over (1.4 wt.-%)Cu-SSZ-13 across the temperature range of 150–700 °C. Also, Leistner et al. [30] compared (2.6 wt.-%)Cu/SAPO-34 and (3.1 wt.-%)Cu/SSZ-13, and found that the higher activity of Cu/SAPO-34 in the ammonia oxidation above 500 °C, and NO x reduction by NH3 at 150 °C appeared due to easily reducible copper species in Cu/SAPO-34 (compared to Cu/SSZ-13; based on H2-TPR analysis). In addition, Cu/SAPO-34 forms less N2O during NH3-SCR as a result of the formation of more stable ammonium nitrates. Recently Gao and Peden published progress in the atomic-level understanding of Cu/SSZ-13 selective catalytic reduction catalyst [31], while Shan et al. [32] and Zhang et al. [28] summarized the state of copper species, standard and fast reaction mechanisms, hydrothermal deactivation mechanism, poisoning resistance, and synthetic methodology mainly over Cu-SSZ-13. Also, Gao [33] summarized Fe-exchanged small-pore zeolite NH3-SCR catalysts, including Fe/SSZ-13, Fe/SAPO-34, Fe/SSZ-39, and high-silica Fe/LTA. The author pointed out their improved high-temperature selectivity (i.e., less N2O as a side product), and hydrothermal stability compared to Cu-containing zeolite-based catalysts prepared under the same conditions. However, the low activity for small pore Fe-exchanged zeolites in NH3-SCR below 300 °C is the main obstacle in their application for automotive catalysis. Thus, this mini-review aims to give a broad picture of the recent developments regarding NO x reduction activity/deactivation and reaction mechanisms of copper-containing SAPO-34 suitable for NH3-SCR for diesel aftertreatment systems. Even though a few important review papers in DeNO x have been published recently about the Cu-containing zeolites [e.g., [9,34]], including Cu-containing chabazite catalysts [e.g., [28,31,35–39]], a specific review on Cu-SAPO-34 themselves is still highly appealed. It seems timely to review these new fundamental findings. 2 Status of Cu species and their impact of NO x conversion The Cu ions in a unit cell of the SAPO-34 structure are possibly located at four different sites: Site I – is located in the ellipsoidal cavity, where cations are coordinated to three framework oxygen atoms of regular 6-MR; Site II – near the center of the ellipsoidal cavity is occupied only in particularly hydrated chabazite; Site III – is in the center of the hexagonal prism, and Site IV - attaches to the 8-membered ring window (Fig. 2 a) [40]. ZCuOH and Z2Cu (where Z stands for the phosphorous atom replaced by silicon in Cu-SAPO-34) serve as two different types of active sites in NH3-SCR (Fig. 2b) [41]. Based on the XAFS data, Deka et al. [42] suggested that the isolated Cu2+ ions in Cu-SAPO-34 are located near the center of 6-MR in the d6r sub-unit of CHA, which was close to the position for Cu ions in Cu-SSZ-13. Although, they did not see any indication of the presence of Cu+, which also prefer to locate within the ellipsoidal cavity just outside the 6-membered rings of SAPO-34 [43]. ZCuOH and thus, [Cu-O-Cu]2+species (the product of dehydrating of Cu(OH)+ at exchange positions) adjoined to 8-membered rings (8-MR) [44,45]. Also, Concepción et al. [46], via combining IR spectroscopy of NO adsorption and theoretical calculations, identified different types of copper species on Cu-SAPO-34, including isolated Cu2+ ions, [Cu-OH]+, [Cu-O-Cu]2+ and small CuO x nanoclusters (typically found on the exterior surface of the molecular sieve crystals). The loading of active copper ions in SAPO-34, copper ions sources and the preparation methods strongly affect the nature within the CHA framework (isolated Cu2+/Cu+ cations, [Cu-O-Cu]2+, CuO x ) and location of Cu species in zeolites, which directly determines the activity and hydrothermal stability of catalysts in NH3-SCR (Table 1 ) as well as the structural/chemical properties of the final catalysts. The isolated Cu2+ ions in Cu-SAPO-34 are generally proposed as the main active species in NH3-SCR, which was determined by using various characterization techniques, e.g., such as EXAFS and DR UV–Vis spectroscopy [48] or EPR spectroscopy [49]. Thus, dozens of literature refers about the preparation procedure of Cu-SAPO-34, including aqueous ion-exchange, ammonia assistant method, impregnation, one-pot hydrothermal method with Cu ions introduced by the structural directing agent, chemical vapor deposition or solid-state ion exchange, etc., to maximize the introduction of copper species in the form of isolated Cu2+ ions. General synthesis strategies of small pore zeolites were reviewed by Moliner et al. [36] while the preparation methods of Cu-CHA were summarized by Xin et al. [37] and Zhang et al. [28]. In the present mini-review, there is a focus on correlations of preparation method-activity of Cu-SAPO-34 (Table 1). The most common method for introducing the active species (i.e., isolated copper ions) for NH3-SCR in SAPO-34 is ion-exchange; although this method does not enable quantitative control of the metal loading. Furthermore, the specific surface area, porosity (i.e., micropore volume), and an extensive crystallinity loss of SAPO-34 dropped severely via the ion-exchange, when SAPO-34 was directly exchanged in an aqueous solution of copper precursors [50–52]. Contrasting to the direct ion-exchange process, H-SAPO-34 experienced a two-step liquid ion-exchange (TLIE) process [53–55]. In the first step, H-SAPO-34 is stirred in an aqueous solution of NH4NO3 at a certain temperature (e.g., 50–80 °C [53,54,56]) or ammonia is adsorbed on Si-(OH)-Al Brønsted acid sites (via ammonia assistant method) [57] to prepare NH4 +-SAPO-34 (thus, hydrogen ions provide charge compensation of the Si-O-Al bonds and coordinate with ammonia species). Secondly, NH4 +-SAPO-34 is exchanged in an aqueous solution of copper precursor to generate Cu-SAPO-34. NH4-form of SAPO-34 has been reported to improve the mobility of Cu ions and promote the ion-exchange rates and levels [58]. However, due to the presence of small pores with a 0.38 nm opening, the distribution of Cu within the zeolitic crystals can be limited leading to the copper species being preferentially located close to the external surface. The catalytic activity of Cu-SAPO-34 was markedly influenced by ion-exchange conditions. E.g., Xu et al. [57] compared Cu-SAPO-34 with x-NH4 +-SAPO-34 prepared by controlling NH3 adsorption temperature (x stands for NH3 adsorption temperature – i.e., 100–300 °C) versus NH4 +-SAPO-34 prepared by liquid ion-exchange. The materials were characterized by the different coordination between NH4 +species and Si-(OH)-Al (Fig. 3 ), i.e., monodentate NH4 + on Si-(OH)-Al (that facilitated the generation of isolated Cu2+during ammonia assistant method) and polydentate NH4 + (that promoted formation of CuO via liquid ion-exchange). CuO x is active species for the side-reaction of NH3 oxidation above 550 °C. Anyway, for the samples with the comparable amounts of NH4 + (prepared via NH3 adsorption (200-Cu-SAPO) and liquid ion-exchange (L-Cu-SAPO) in Fig. 3), the content of isolated Cu2+species was higher for the copper-exchanged SAPO-34. As the isolated Cu2+ species are the active sites for Cu-SAPO-34 [40,55], thus, the higher NO x conversion was reached over the L-Cu-SAPO catalyst. Xue et al. [40] prepared Cu-SAPO-34 by loading various Cu2+ concentrations via ion-exchange process, and showed that excessive copper loading produced CuO x species (more than 2.89 wt.-% of Cu) would inhibit NO conversions during the whole temperature range. Cu-SAPO-34 only with isolated Cu2+ ions are hardly obtained using liquid ion-exchange. Gao et al. [53] found that CuO x co-exists with the isolated Cu2+ ions in Cu-SAPO-34 even with extremely low Cu loading and applying dilute copper acetate solution (0.01 M), very moderate temperatures (50 °C), short contact time (1 h), and final calcination of the materials at 600 °C for 5 h. However, upon heating (above 750 °C), the position of the copper ions changes, and they enter the 6-membered ring hexagonal prism of the CHA framework. E.g., Vennestrøm et al. [59] visualized the migration of copper species from the surface region upon activation of Cu-SAPO-34 by characteristic X-ray intensity maps (on more than 10 crystals randomly chosen) before and after activation at 750 °C (Fig. 4 ). An appropriate heat treatment activated the inhomogeneously distributed copper species to generate the desired copper ions. The homogenous distribution of copper species - confirmed by the plane concentration across the crystal plane, leads to the enhanced activity of the material in NH3-SCR (more than 5-fold) compared to the conventional Cu-SSZ-13 per Cu atom. In this studies the copper acetate - Cu(CH3COO)2, was applied as copper precursor for Cu-SAPO-34 preparation, which as indicated by the Wang et al. [60] lead to above 90% of NO x conversion in the widest temperature window (100–550 °C) in NH3-SCR among other applied copper precursors (e.g., CuSO4, Cu(NO3)2, CuCl2). Furthermore, there are several studies where the authors compare the activity of Cu-SAPO-34 in NH3-SCR prepared by different methods (e.g., [54,61]). E.g., Yan et al. [61] compared Cu-SAPO-34 that was prepared by ion-exchange, wet-mixing, and impregnation. They found the isolated Cu2+ species (more active and stable due to steric hindrance) in the ellipsoidal cavity (Site I) for the ion-exchange sample, and near the 8-ring window (Site IV) in the samples prepared via wet-mixing and impregnation. Xue et al. [40] also found a direct correlation between the SCR reaction rates and the number of isolated Cu2+ ions. Overall, as can be seen from the data presented in Table 1, a great variety of Cu-exchanged SAPO-34 catalytic systems with copper content in the range of 0.89–4.5 wt.-% have been developed and tested for pointing Cu2+ ions as active species in NH3-SCR. The investigated catalysts allowed to obtain more than 80% NO x conversion in the broad range of 100–600 °C with N2O formation lower than 15 ppm (according to data gathered in Table 1, pos. 5–25), depending on the applied catalyst preparation procedure as well as pre-treatment and reaction conditions (i.e., presence of H2O, CO x or SO x , excluding high-temperature hydrothermal treatment that will be discussed below), etc. However, during ion-exchange SAPO-34 undergoes structural damage to a different extent via irreversible hydrolysis. Furthermore, the method is time-consuming while the copper content is rather difficult to control. Thus, other synthesis methods i.e., the impregnation, one-pot synthesis, or the solid-state ion-exchange become meaningful. Impregnation is straightforward to implement and of low cost, because it does not require an excess solution. Also, the metal loading can be precisely controlled, while the particle size distribution is often broad. Also, the dispersion can be low, since the particle distribution of the impregnated metals is stochastic, which may lead to particle agglomeration and formation of CuO x . Cu-SAPO-34 obtained via impregnation remove more than 80% NO x in a broad temperature range of 150–550 °C with less than 14 ppm N2O formation (according to data gathered in Table 1, pos. 26–47, excluding high-temperature hydrothermal treatment that will be discussed below). Otherwise, the one-pot hydrothermal synthesis method realized the direct introduction of Cu species, and similar to ion-exchange allows to obtain Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts with isolated copper ions as the dominant copper species. Ren et al. [62] first reported a one-pot method with a copper complex made from CuSO4⋅5H2O and tetraethylenepentamine (molar ratio of 1/1, Cu-TEPA for short) as the template for the preparation of Cu-SSZ-13. Regarding the synthesis of Cu-SAPO-34, e.g., Niu et al. [63] studied the influence of calcination temperature (500–800 °C), Cu loading (2.96–5.15 wt.-%, n(Cu-TEPA)/n(Al) = 0.03–0.20), and co-template concentrations (n(PA)/n(Al) = 1.2–1.8, PA - propylamine) on catalytic activity of the final Cu/SAPO-34 catalysts, and found that the materials with 3.44 wt.-% Cu loading (n(Cu-TEPA)/n(Al) = 0.16) and calcined at 700 °C possessed more than 80% of NO x conversion in the range of 200–500 °C (even after high-temperature hydrothermal treatment; 750–800 °C for 16 h, Table 1, pos. 57). Other materials suffer from too excessive Cu content (5.15 wt.-%) which was harmful to their hydrothermal stability. Further studies indicate that the Cu loading of one-pot Cu-CHA catalysts can be lowered by an ion-exchange with an NH4NO3 solution (i.e., a reverse ion-exchange; e.g., [64,65]). Regarding the optimal copper loading for active and stable Cu-SAPO-34, Tang et al. [66] reported 1.70 wt.-% of Cu, while Wang et al. [67] found 3.91 wt.-%, respectively, which indicate that this depends on the loading for each SAPO-34 support with certain Si compositions (determining the acid sites density). Martíez-Franco et al. applied a mixture of diethylamine (DEA) and Cu-TEPA [68] or DEA, tetraethylammonium bromide (TEABr), and Cu-TEPA as the templates in the synthesis of Cu-SAPO-34 [69]. The NO conversion over (3.3 wt.-%)Cu-SAPO-34 maintained a level above 80% between 200 and 500 °C and the conversion decreased about 10% over the whole temperature range after hydrothermal aging at 750 °C for 13 h [69]. Following these studies, various Cu-complexes and synthesis conditions have been reported to direct the one-pot method of Cu-SAPO-34, such as e.g., Cu-TEPA and MOR [70,71], or Cu-TETA and TEAOH (Cu(triethylenetetramine)2+ and tetraethylammonium hydroxide , respectively) [42]. Overall, Cu-SAPO-34 prepared via one-pot hydrothermal method present a class of highly active and N2 selective catalysts (i.e., more than 80% NO conversion at 150–650 °C with less than 20 ppm N2O; according to data gathered in Table 1, pos. 46–66, not considering the data collected for the thermally treated materials). However, again, concerning the influence of the preparation variables (e.g., the different total amount of copper, variety of applied metal promoters and supports) as well as pre-treatment and reaction conditions, the comparison of activity over Cu-SAPO-34 is limited. Fine CuO powders chemically deposited on the surface of H-SAPO-34 can react with Brønsted acids on the framework via the solid-state ion-exchange described as follows (Eq. (1)): CuO + H-SAPO-34 → Cu-SAPO-34 + H2O↑ (Eq. (1)) Thus, the solid-state ion-exchange (SSIE) allows obtaining valuable control of the Cu content (up to 3.7 wt.-% of Cu for maximum content of Cu2+ ions [72]) in the SAPO-34 framework. Zamadics et al. [73] first reported the preparation of Cu-SAPO-34 via the SSIE method. In another successful example, Wang et al. [74] investigated a series of SAPO-34 catalysts with varying Cu loading (ranging from 0.7 up to 3.0 wt.-%; introduced by thermal treatment of 120 °C/4 h, 600 °C/5 h, 800 °C/12 h). The amount of isolated Cu2+ was found to increase with increasing Cu loading up to 2.0 wt.-%; while the amount of Cu x O y clusters (dimeric or oligomeric Cu species) continuously increased up to 3.0 wt.-%, and catalyze NH3 oxidation above 400 °C (Fig. 5a). Gao et al. [75] studied solid-state reaction between SAPO-34 and CuO under different calcination temperatures (600–800 °C) and times (1–16 h) and found that a portion of CuO (∼67%, confirmed by H2-TPR and EPR analyses, Fig. 5b) converted to isolated Cu2+ ions after the SSIE treatment at 800 °C for 16 h. Otherwise, an enhanced amount of Cu2+ ions (compared to mechanical mixing) was reported for Cu-SAPO-34 prepared via ball milling [76]. As can be seen from Table 1, pos. 67–72, significantly fewer materials prepared via SSIE were investigated in NH3-SCR. The investigated catalysts allowed to obtain more than 80% NO x conversion in the broad range of 175–500 °C with N2O, NO x formation lower than < 15 ppm/10%. Contrary to conventional Cu-SAPO-34 applied in NH3-SCR, the preparation and activity of micro-/mesoporous catalysts remain an open field for scientists. The micro-/mesoporous SAPO-34 is mostly prepared by a top-down approach that generally involves performing post-synthesis procedures, i.e., the mesopores are generated during the demetallation of the framework. The modification of porosity of SAPO-34 was reported to affect acidity as well as the content, form, and reducibility of the introduced copper species. Verboekend et al. [77] reported that SAPOs (including SAPO-34) amorphize strongly in an aqueous solution of HCl, H4EDTA, Na2H2EDTA as well as NaOH (requiring the use of tetrapropylammonium hydroxide or diethylamine to preserve their crystallinity during treatment). E.g., Rutkowska et al. [78] observed dissolution and formation of new phases for commercial SAPO-34 treated with an aqueous solution of 0.2 M Na2H2EDTA. The activity of the final (5 wt.-%) Cu/SAPO-34 significantly decreased (especially above 300 °C) in comparison to non-treated Cu/SAPO-34. The catalytic data for other catalysts (SAPO-34 modified in the presence of other different 0.2 M bases or acids (NaOH, TPAOH, HCl) was not provided. Otherwise, as a bottom-up approach, Liu et al. [79] applied a hydrothermal method by using Cu-TEPA and N,N-diisopropylethylamine (DIPEA) in the preparation of Cu-SAPO-34 with intracrystalline mesopores with different sizes (Fig. 6a). In other successful examples, the micro-/mesopores SAPO-34 was also prepared by using MOR and the long-chain organic compound: [C22H45 N+(CH3)2 C6H12 N+(CH3)2 C6H13]Br2 (C22–6 – 6-Br2) [80], or a hard-template method using CaCO3 (Fig. 6b) [81,82]. An enhanced activity (compared to conventional Cu-SAPO-34) of the catalyst (>80% NO conversion in the range of 150–500 °C) could be attributed to the improved accessibility of reactants to catalytically active sites. Furthermore, the co-presence of H2O/SO2 in the feed gas was reported to have no obvious effect on NO x conversion of such materials [80,82]. SO2 - as a constituent of diesel exhaust gas (coming from residues in the fuel as well as those from lubricant oils, even at the ultra-low sulfur diesel (ULSD) levels containing less than 15 ppm sulfur), has a significant impact on the activity of Cu-SAPO-34. The sulfate species (ammonia sulfate and ammonium bisulfate) are formed during NH3-SCR at the low reaction temperature, and their decomposition temperature is above ∼300–350 °C. Whereas higher temperatures (over 600 °C) are needed to desorb other S-containing (e.g., Cu x SO y ) species [83]. More stable sulfates were reported to be produced in the presence of H2O and O2 [41]. Zhang et al. [84] found that the formation of ammonium sulfate ((NH4)2SO4) species poison the active sites of commercial Cu-SAPO-34 and block its pores as well as competitive adsorption between SO2 and NO x , which induce the inhibition of NH3-SCR activity below 300 °C (above 300 °C no evident effect of SO2 was observed). However, the surface sulfur species decomposed above 500 °C in an O2/N2 mixture, such that catalytic activity of Cu-SAPO-34 was retained. Similar conclusions were given later by Hammershøi et al. [85]. Jangjou et al. [83] reported that NH3 enhanced the adsorption of SO2, as the presence of NH3 opens up the ammonium sulfate formation pathway under standard NH3-SCR at 210 °C. Contrary to such studies, Kumar et al. [86] and Wijayanti et al. [87] observed no significant impact on total NH3 storage capacity over pre-sulfated samples. Furthermore, the poisoning with SO3 resulted in a more severe deactivation compared with using SO2 [86,88]. Shen et al. [89] and Wijayanti et al. [87] found that the amount of isolated Cu2+ noticeably declines after SO2 exposure, thus less copper species in Cu-SAPO-34 is available for participating in the redox cycle (based on EPR and H2-TPR analyses). Su et al. [90] reported three sulfate species that existed on the Cu/CHA catalyst surface, including H2SO4, CuSO4, and Al2(SO4)3. The H2SO4 species decompose at 450 °C, while the CuSO4 and Al2(SO4)3 species decomposed above 650 °C, thus, preventing the complete recovery of pre-sulfated Cu/SAPO-34. The modification of Cu-containing SAPO-34 with other transition and/or rare earth metals lead to improved SO2 resistance, e.g., for Fe/Cu-SAPO-34 (NO x conversion decreased from 86 to 80% after introducing 50 ppm SO2) [91] or for Cu-Mn/SAPO-34 (NO x conversion decreased from 97% to 63–72% after introducing 500–1500 ppm SO2) [92], etc. Thus, the precise preparations of Cu-SAPO-34 involving copper loading and its distribution are still the challenges in the development of efficient, high-performing, and resistant catalysts. Overall, based on the data gathered in Table 1, the catalysts prepared by different methods show activity in the temperatures range of 100–650 °C (> 80% NO conversion) and formation of by-products below 20 ppm. Otherwise, a limited number of studies focus on the alkali metal-poisoned Cu-SAPO-34. E.g., Ma et al. [93] found that Cu-SAPO-34 stays resistant up to 0.5 wt.-% of K (among 0.5–2.5 wt.-% K loading). The higher loading leads to a significant decrease in NO x activity ascribed to the reduction of the active sites, the transformation of the isolated Cu+/Cu2+ to Cu x O y clusters. Wang et al. [94] designed a novel ceria-promoted copper-based catalysts (Cu-Ce/SAPO-34) containing rich Brønsted acid sites (Si-OH-Al, P-OH) that demonstrated exceptional resistance against alkali (K), alkaline earth (Ca), and heavy metal (Pb) poisoning during NH3-SCR. Zha et al. [95] develop hollandite Mn-Ti oxide promoted Cu-SAPO-34 for NH3-SCR, where the hollandite Mn-Ti oxides acted as a protective layer to trap alkali metals ions. 3 Hydrothermal stability 3.1 High-temperature hydrothermal treatment SAPO-34 is stable up to 1000 °C (without water) [120]. After thermal treatment, desilication occurs for SAPO-34 and the isolated silicon atoms tend to cluster into silicon islands [120,121]. However, water always emits from internal combustion engines and the exhaust temperature can reach above 600–700 °C during diesel particulate filter regeneration, thus such conditions should be applied in catalyzed NH3-SCR to meet the requirements of increasingly stringent emission regulations. For instance, hydrothermal aging at 800 °C for 16 h can be compared with a 135,000 mile vehicle-aged SCR catalyst [122]. Also temperatures below 100 °C are important, especially during the start-stop and idle process. Yu et al. [99] have shown that H2O in the inlets could greatly enhance NH3-SCR over Cu-SAPO-34 activity in the whole temperature range ranging from 120 °C (due to improved copper species reducibility and catalyst acidity, Fig. 7a) to 600 °C (due to deteriorated NH3 oxidation during NH3-SCR, and side-products during NH3 oxidation). In 2011, Fickel et al. [27] reported that copper-exchanged small-pore zeolite catalysts possessed higher NH3-SCR activity between 150 and 500 °C and are much more hydrothermal stable than the medium-pore zeolites, e.g., Cu-ZSM-5. In particular, SAPO-34 has drawn much attention not only due to exceptional NH3-SCR activity and high N2 selectivity but also due to its superior hydrothermal durability. The superior hydrothermal stability is attributed to the small size of the pores (0.38 × 0.38 nm) preventing detached Al(OH)3 moieties (which are 0.503 nm longer than the pore size) from exiting the framework [27,123]. The aluminum hydroxide moiety settles back into the framework when the catalyst is cooled down again [27,39,124]. Cu-SAPO-34 is hydrothermally stable and catalytically active as the isomorphous zeolite, Cu-SSZ-13 (Fig. 7b). Following such studies, Cu-SAPO-34 was reported to possess much higher hydrothermal stability compared with Cu-SSZ-13 after treating at 800 °C for 16 h [125]. Su et al. [101] pointed out desilication (versus the migration of extra-framework Al and P atoms to Si defects and a certain degree of the aggregation of Cu species) in hydrothermally aged (800 °C for 12 h) Cu-SAPO-34 and dealumination (the detached Al(OH)3 species deactivated the Cu species by the transformation of isolated Cu2+ ions to CuAlO x species) in hydrothermally aged SSZ-13. In general, Cu-exchanged SAPO-34 after high-temperature pretreatment (700–800 °C, up to 50 h) showed the same or a slightly higher NO x reduction activity than the fresh ion-exchnged samples [27,56,61,122,125] (Table 1, pos. 5–25). High hydrothermal stability was also observed for Cu-SAPO-34 prepared using impregnation (Table 1, pos. 26–47) and the one-pot method (Table 1, pos. 48–66). Nevertheless, it is still a blank to investigate Cu-SAPO-34 under more severe hydrothermal deactivation conditions. Improved activity over aged samples corresponds to the isolated Cu2+ species that were formed via migrating CuO x species from the external surface into the ion-exchange sites of Cu-containing SAPO-34 after hydrothermal treatment [67,125,126]. Furthermore, CuO x species were reported to more easily transfer to isolated Cu2+ species via migrating into the framework from the external surface of SAPO-34 for the larger-sized catalysts (6 μm) rather than the smaller-sized ones (3 μm) [110]. Moreover, CuO x is transformed into metallic Cu with the absence of oxygen firstly at high-temperature (∼700 °C), and then metallic Cu is further re-oxidized into isolated Cu2+species during high-temperature hydrothermal treatment [56]. The deactivation in catalytic activity for the materials treated above 800 °C was explained by the collapse of zeolite structure and/or Cu agglomeration [122]. Thus, prolonged hydrothermal treatment would still cause framework degradation for Cu-SAPO-34. Schmieg et al. [122] insisted that copper species would aggregate and form CuO x under high-temperature hydrothermal conditions (i.e., 800 °C for 120 h, 12.5 vol.-% H2O/air balance). As the status of Cu species is vital to NH3-SCR activity, so numerous efforts have been devoted to how to keep more isolated Cu2+ species for Cu-SAPO-34 during hydrothermal treatment. E.g., Petitto and Delahay [127] reported Cu-SAPO-34 with only 1.2 wt.-% of Si, exhibited very high stability upon aging at 850 °C for 5 h in the presence of 10 vol.-% H2O. Si(xOAl) (x = 1–3) structures are conducive to the stabilization of isolated Cu2+, thus enhancing the stability to severe hydrothermal treatment [69,128]. The presence of numerous Si islands Si(0OAl) (thus, less isolated Si (Si(4OAl))) in Cu-SAPO-34 was proved to be detrimental to NH3-SCR (e.g., [55,68,129]). Also, the high content of Si(4OAl) and Si(0OAl) was detrimental to the high-temperature hydrothermal stability of Cu-SAPO-34. Zhang et al. [113] found that Cu-SAPO-18/34 possessed a higher Si(xOAl) (x = 1–4) structure than Cu-SAPO-34, which facilitated the generation of more isolated copper ions (Cu2+ and Cu+) and thus, suppressed the formation of CuO x . Furthermore, Tang et al. [66] found preserved activity and stability for hydrothermally aged material (at 950 °C, 4 h, 10 vol.-% H2O, air balance) with lower/optimal copper loading (1.7 wt.-% versus 3.91 wt.-%) due to CuO x re-dispersion into Cu2+ on abundant free hydroxyls. Of course, the optimal copper species loading varied among preparation conditions [68,130] (e.g., optimal loading of 3.4 wt.-% of Cu was found for the materials prepared via one-pot hydrothermal synthesis method and steamed at 750 °C for 13 h). However, a significant loss of catalytic activity (after hydrothermal treatment) was observed for Cu-SAPO-34 containing 3.4 wt.-% of Cu, while the crystallinity framework of Cu-SAPO-34, with medium-high Cu content (6.0–10.4 wt.-%), collapsed [68]. In general, other Cu-containing zeolites have all shown lower hydrothermal stability when increasing Cu content (e.g., [131,132]). To further optimize the hydrothermal stability, the Cu-based SAPO-34 was doped with other elements, e.g., rare earth metals such as Ce [111] or La [107,108]. Contrary to aged Cu-SAPO-34 (700 °C, 10 vol.-% H2O/air, 10 h) the activity of the rare-earth metals modified Cu-SAPO-34 was preserved (more than 93% NO x conversion was maintained at 175–350 °C with only a slight decline above 350 °C). The introduction of Ce or La could reduce the aggregation of copper species and mitigate the dealumination progress of the zeolite framework during hydrothermal aging. Ma et al. [105] showed that Cu-SAPO-34 based on (F − anions modified H-SAPO-34) exhibited high-temperature stability and NH3-SCR activity in a broadened temperature window. 3.2 Low-temperature hydrothermal treatment Although, Cu-containing SAPO-34 has a good high-temperature hydrothermal ability, the low-temperature hydrothermal aging (<100 °C) is fatal to the destruction of Cu-SAPO-34, causing the loss of low-temperature SCR performance, and thus limiting the promotion and application of these catalysts [56,133,134]. E.g., Leistner and Olsson [133] reported that the NH3-SCR activity of Cu-SAPO-34 decreased significantly (more than 90% conversion decrease of Cu-SAPO-34 at 200 °C) after exposing the catalysts in H2O containing feed at 70 °C for 9 h. However, SAPO-34 synthesized using MOR as a template showed lower stability (due to the large quantity of the Si-O-Al bonds in the material prone to being attacked by H2O) than those using TEAOH or TEA [53,134,135]. E.g., the activity of Cu/SAPO-34 (SAPO-34 synthesized by using MO, TEA, TEAOH, ACS material, Cu deposition via incipient wetness impregnation) after low-temperature pretreatment (Exp-4: 8 vol.-% O2, 5 vol.-% H2O at 70 °C for 5 h) are compared in Fig. 8 a [134]. Cu/SAPO-34(TEAOH) and (TEA) exhibited a minor low-temperature deactivation and mostly recovered their original activities during NH3-SCR (e.g., Exp-7, Fig 8a). Also, Du et al. [117] proved that the more Si atoms inducing more Si-O-Al bonds within the zeolite framework were more vulnerable to H2O. Thus, the one-pot synthesized Cu-SAPO-34 prepared by using PA as a co-template showed superior hydrothermal stability under low/high temperatures compared with Cu-SAPO-34 prepared with TEA or MOR). Furthermore, not only SDA but also the Cu-exchange method influences the tolerance for the low-temperature deactivation caused by exposure to H2O. Woo et al. [118] found Cu-SAPO-34(TEAOH, TEA, MO) prepared with the solid-state ion-exchange method as more active and less prone for the deactivation than samples prepared via impregnation. Several research groups (e.g., [53,67,136]) proposed Si-O-Al bonds opening and P-O-Al bonds opening (causing the tetrahedral Al atoms to migrate outside the framework to form octahedrally coordinated Al atoms and amorphous silicon complexes, Fig. 8b) as the potential deactivation mechanism. In extreme cases, the chabazite framework of Cu-SAPO-34 completely collapsed during such treatments (e.g., [115,134,137]). Recently Wang et al. [115,138] reported that even long-term storage under ambient conditions with moisture can lead to substantial damage to the Cu-SAPO-34 structure. Furthermore, the low-temperature Cu-SAPO-34 degradation appears due to the transformation of active Cu2+ ions to inert copper species, such as Cu-aluminate-like species or CuO x species [100,115,139,140]. E.g., Wang et al. [115] claimed that the main reason for the Cu-SAPO-34 activity failure at low temperatures in the presence of water is the formation of Cu-aluminate species, resulting from the interaction between Cu(OH)2 (coming from the detachment of Cu2+ions from cationic positions) and terminal Al species (coming from irreversible hydrolysis of the SAPO-34 framework). Furthermore, the isolated Cu2+ ions on the exchangeable sites of SAPO-34 can stabilize the framework structure by preventing H2O to attack the Si-O-Al bonds during the low-temperature hydrothermal treatment (Fig. 8b, based on ex-situ DRIFTS and NMR results) [67]. Thus, as mentioned above as the high Cu loading has a detrimental effect on the high-temperature hydrothermal stability of Cu-SAPO-34, the Cu loading of the catalysts should be optimized to balance hydrothermal stability both at low- as well as high-temperature ranges. Many efforts have been attempted to improve the stability of Cu-SAPO-34 under humid conditions by utilizing NH4 + and other co-cations. Mess et al. [136] found that the hydrothermal stability of SAPO-34 was greatly improved by that replacing protons on the Brønsted acid sites with NH4 + species. NH4 + formed on Si-(OH)-Al sites prevented structures from H2O attacking during the liquid Cu exchange process which was further confirmed based on the ex-situ IR and NMR analyses [57]. Furthermore, Guan et al. [114] investigated the impact of Ce on the structural stability of CuCe-SAPO-34 in NH3-SCR. Ce species were reported to protect Cu2+ ions and prevent the dealumination (due to formation of Si-O(Ce)-Al bond) in the process of low-temperature hydrothermal aging (70 °C for 16 h). Other second cations (Y or Nd for example) were introduced into Cu-SAPO-34 to enhance hydrothermal resistance [109,111,112]. Furthermore, the low-temperature hydrothermal stability of Cu-SAPO-34 was found to be closely related to its average crystallite size. E.g., Huang et al. [137] reported improved stability of Cu-SAPO-34 with controlled zeolite crystal size (1–13 µm) by using various amounts of seeds (with otherwise identical synthesis conditions) and claimed that the more surface enrichment of Si-O-Al sites (the larger the crystallite size). Thus, the smaller crystallite size (more seeds) is preferred (Fig. 9a), while the coupling of smaller crystallite size with a higher degree of Cu2+ exchange would lead to enhanced low-temperature stability for Cu-SAPO-34. Lin et al. [141] proved that a higher content of Si islands was detrimental to the low-temperature hydrothermal stability. Regarding the regeneration of Cu-SAPO-34, e.g., Ma et al. [142] reported reversible (Cu(OH)2 - deactivated Cu species can be transformed back to active Cu2+ ions during high-temperature regeneration, e.g., at 550 °C) and irreversible (the accumulation of CuAl2O4-like species leads to permanent loss of active Cu2+ ions) deactivation during low-temperature treatment. Surprisingly, Woo et al. [143] proposed regeneration of Cu/SAPO-34(MO), i.e., the Si clusters are transformed back to Si-O-H bonds, and thereafter transferred back to the framework only at a certain level of water concentration, (i.e., 10 vol.-%). Although, low-temperature treatment is more severe for Cu-containing SAPO-34, not many research was conducted so far in this direction (Table 1). 4 Reaction mechanism NH3-SCR over Cu-containing SAPO-34 proceeds through the adsorption stage of NH3 and/or NO (according to the Eley-Rideal (E-R) and/or Langmuir-Hinshelwodd (L-H) mechanisms) to form surface nitrites and/or ammonium nitrates, followed by their decomposition into N2 and H2O. The mechanisms are generally based on in situ spectroscopic investigation of the nature of the intermediate compounds (e.g., [29,96]), however, in such a case it is difficult to distinguish them between active species and spectators. Although, the most available literature focuses on the investigation of Cu-SSZ-13 in NH3-SCR, in this section only the studies regarding Cu-containing SAPO-34 are provided. In general, NH3-SCR is based on the Cu2+/Cu+ redox cycle, where Cu2+ is reduced by NH3 and/or NO and Cu+ is oxidized by O2 (which is considered as the rate-determining step). NH3-SCR reaction pathway over Cu-SAPO-34 changes with the change of the reaction temperature, which is related to a change in the character of the active Cu+ species [139]. Woo et al. [139] suggested that below 250 °C, Cu+ species are solvated by two NH3-ligands forming mobile Cu(NH3)2+ complexes, whereas Cu2+ forms fourfold coordinated complexes such as Cu(NH3)4 2+, Cu(OH)(NH3)3+, and complexes containing a mixture of NH3 and NO x ligands. e.g., [Cu(OH)(NH3)3(NO)]+ - for the first time, spectroscopically approved over Cu-containing zeolite-based catalysts by Tarach et al. [144] According to the widely accepted NH3-SCR pathways [e.g., [144,145]], upon formation of [Cu(OH)(NH3)3(NO)]+ intermediate, the neighboring NH3 and NO ligands will rearrange to create NN bond via the nitosamide (NH2NO) or ammonium nitrite (NH4NO2) intermediates. NH2NO and NH4NO2 will subsequently decompose into N2 and H2O to complete the reduction part of NH3-SCR, as confirmed by Mao et al. [146] based on periodic DFT calculations. For fast NH3-SCR, Cu+/NH4 + was oxidized by NO2 with the formation Cu2+ and NH4NO2, which further decompose to N2 and H2O (Fig 10a). Zhang et al. [58,113] based on in situ DRIFTS at 150–400 °C found that NH3-SCR over Cu-SAPO-34 followed only L-H mechanism, where adsorbed NO3 − and NO2 − reacted with adsorbed NH3 on acid sites to produce NH4NO2 that decompose to N2 and H2O, according to the Eq. (1)-9 (where g represented the gas phase; ad represented the species to be adsorbed): O2 ( g ) ↔ 2O ( a ) (1) O ( a ) + NO ( g ) ↔ NO2 ( g ) (2) Cu+ + NO ( g ) + O2 ( g ) ↔ Cu2+-NO3 − ( ad ) (3) Cu+ + NO2 ( g ) ↔ Cu2+-NO2 − (a) (4) Cu2+-NO3 − ( ad ) + NO ( g ) → Cu2+-NO2 − ( ad ) + NO2 ( g ) (5) Cu2+ + NH3 ( g ) ↔ Cu+-NH2 ( ad ) + H+ (6) NH3 ( g ) + H+ ↔ NH4+ ( ad ) (7) Cu2+-NO3 − ( ad ) + NH4 + ( ad ) + NO ( g ) ↔ Cu2+-(NH4 +NO3 −) ( ad ) + NO ( g ) ↔ Cu2+-(NH4 +NO2 −) ( ad ) + NO2 ( g ) ↔ Cu2+ + NO2 ( g ) + N2 ( g ) + 2 H2O ( g ) (L-H, 8) NH4+ ( ad ) + Cu2+-NO2 − ( ad ) ↔ Cu2+-(NH4 +NO2 −) ( ad ) ↔ Cu2+ + N2 ( g ) + 2H2O ( g ) (L-H, 9) On the other hand, NH4NO3 could allow a side reaction leading to undesired N2O, e.g., Yu et al. [49] found at 290 °C that NH4NO2 species decomposes easily to N2 and H2O, while the formation of N2O is related to the existence of NH4NO3. Contrary to these studies, in an early report, Wang et al. [96] based on the in situ DRIFTS analysis claimed that the reaction mechanism of Cu-SAPO-34 proceeded with the formation of NH4NO3 and NH4NO2 on the Lewis acid sites. The Brønsted acid sites can reserve a large amount of NH3 [96]. NH4NO3 was suggested to be reduced to N2 in the presence of NO below 100 °C, which accounts for the enhanced low-temperature activity of Cu-SAPO-34. These results were further supported by Ma et al. [29] who also claimed (based on in situ DRIFTS and TPD results) that in the low-temperature range, the ammonium nitrates from the reaction between surface ammonia and nitrates are the key intermediates that are further reduced by gas-phase NO to form N2 and H2O. The [Cu(NH3)2]+ complexes become the intermediate starting the oxidation half-cycle. A pair of [Cu(NH3)2]+ complexes activated O2 with the formation of the intermediate [Cu(NH3)2]+-O2-[Cu(NH3)2]+, which is suggested to be the rate-limiting step for NH3-SCR [145,147,148]. Wang et al. [149] using isothermal microcalorimetry combined with mass spectrometry found out that a higher amount of O2 adsorbs over the [Cu(NH3)2]+ complexes than over the framework-bound Cu+ species at temperatures below 200 °C. In the next step, electron transfer from Cu to O results in Cu ions oxidation. O2 dissociation and NO2 formation occur on complexes in the presence of NO. Finally, the newly formed [Cu(NH3)2]2+-O-[Cu(NH3)2]2+ hydrolyze in the presence of H2O, restoring two [Cu(OH)(NH3)2]+ adducts (Fig. 10b) [150]. Wan et al. [44] reported that H2O not only accelerates the re-oxidation half cycle but also promotes the migration of the Cu species, forming active sites. Shi et al. [47] investigated the influence of water on NH3-SCR over Cu-SAPO-34 using first-principles calculations and suggested that at low temperatures the Cu(NH3)2 +-Cu(NH3)(H2O)+ complexes can lower the energy barriers of O2 activation, enhancing the NO conversions. Above 350 °C, the inlet of water may no longer decrease the energy barriers of O2 activation but inhibit NH3 oxidation, and thus, enhance NH3-SCR. The apparent activation energies for NH3-SCR over Cu-SAPO-34 varies in the range of 32–34 kJ mol−1 [40,126] and is lower than that reported for Cu-SSZ-13 (40–41 kJ mol−1 [151,152]) possible due to severe intra-particle diffusion limitation of Cu-SAPO-34 [153]. 5 Conclusion and perspectives Cu-SAPO-34 has demonstrated enhanced low-temperature NO x reduction and N2 selectivity, as well as excellent hydrothermal stability at high temperatures. Thus, this works provides a broad picture of the property-activity correlations of Cu-containing SAPO-34 for investigation for NH3-SCR. The effect of the preparation methods on the catalytic properties of Cu-SAPO-34 is discussed. The high- and low-temperature hydrothermal stability of Cu-SAPO-34 is evaluated. Furthermore, the advances in the understanding of the reaction mechanisms are reviewed. Researchers have investigated many catalytic systems in the past several years as discussed above. Still, challenges remain in developing a simply prepared Cu modified SAPO-34 with enhanced NH3-SCR activity, high hydrothermal stability, and resistance of poisons, i.e., SO2, alkali/alkaline earth metal poisoning (e.g., K, Ca, Na, Mg), or phosphorus poisoning. Furthermore, the high- or low-temperature aging is often done for short durations which highlights the challenges associated with testing the stability of the powders materials (compared to the monoliths). Also, conditions applied in the preparation of the materials, pointed out by Datye and Votsmeier [154] - degreening at 700 °C in 10 vol.-% O2, 5 vol.-% of CO2 and H2O, followed by the aging at 800 °C for 50 h for diesel exhaust applications – highlight the gap between in the research and industry applications. Besides the application of IR spectroscopy and DFT calculations, more detailed in situ and operando spectroscopic studies, as well as transient kinetic investigations, are required to further understand the active sites and intermediates, structure-activity, and reaction mechanisms, also in the presence of CO x , SO x , H2O, etc. Fig. 4 Declaration of Competing Interest The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper. coredata.dc:description: In recent years, Cu-exchanged small pore zeolites, such as Cu-SSZ-13 and Cu-SAPO-34, have been commercially applied in diesel after-treatment systems. Several tremendous research articles have been reported on Cu-CHA investigated in NH3-SCR, which makes this mini-review timely to provide inspirations for future material development. In the main body of this work, the preparation procedures of Cu-SAPO-34, the operating temperature ranges with NO x reduction activity/by-product formation, the poisoning and deactivation mechanisms as well as NH3-SCR reaction mechanisms over copper-containing SAPO-34 are reviewed. Last but not least, a summary and outlook are given to highlight promising candidates together with expected research directions in developing Cu-SAPO-34 for NH3-SCR.
coredata.dc:title: Recent progress in the selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 on Cu-SAPO-34 catalysts
